tweet: Read more from my questions to Lt. Gen. Berger and Admiral Moran here  ⤵ https://www.wicker.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2019/4/wicker-presses-navy-marine-corps-leaders-on-seapower-priorities …

“The worst part about [continuing resolutions] for us is the unpredictability… So at best, you try to hold your head above water with what you’ve got, but what really happens is an erosion of readiness.” – Lt. Gen. Berger to @SASCMajority

“The stability of a capital intensive force like the @USNavy with large contracts … really affects our vendor base...They need predictability to be efficient, to hire appropriately, and to be able to maintain our equipment” - Admiral Bill Moran to @SASCMajority.
Lt. Gen. Berger and Admiral Moran made clear that budget uncertainty, including a continuing resolution or budget sequester, could be devastating for our industrial base and our ability to fight.
As Lt. Gen. Berger told @SASCMajority, “I don’t believe there is any more versatile capability than an embarked Marine force on an amphibious ship.”

Though Congress appropriated $350M in advance procurement funding, the current @OMBpress budget proposal removes amphibs for FY2020. I think we have the flexibility and capability to find a way to stick with the plan that Congress enacted last year.

ICYMI: This morning I asked the presumptive service leaders of the @USNavy and @USMC about their support for important shipbuilding programs, including the LPD and LHA class amphibious ships that are built in Mississippi. https://youtu.be/or7yjHrpQq8
